SEARCH
Package gw.api.address.formatter

Class CountryAddressFormatUtil

java.lang.Object
gw.api.address.formatter.CountryAddressFormatUtil
public final class CountryAddressFormatUtil extends Object
Utility class for handling country-specific address formatting. This class provides static methods to obtain formatters and builders for addressing formats based on different countries.

  • Constructor Details

    • CountryAddressFormatUtil

      public CountryAddressFormatUtil()

  • Method Details

    • getCountryAddressFormatter

      public static CountryAddressFormatter getCountryAddressFormatter(Country country)
      Retrieves a CountryAddressFormatter for a specific country. If a specific formatter for the country is not available, it returns the default formatter CountryAddressDefaultFormatter.
      Parameters:
      country - The country for which the address formatter is required.
      Returns:
      A CountryAddressFormatter specific to the given country, or the default formatter if a specific one is not available.

    • getCountryAddressFormatBuilder

      public static CountryAddressFormatBuilder getCountryAddressFormatBuilder(String text)
      Creates a new CountryAddressFormatBuilder instance. This builder is used for constructing a formatted address string.
      Parameters:
      text - The initial text to be used in the address format builder.
      Returns:
      A new instance of CountryAddressFormatBuilder.

    • getCountryAddressWrapper

      public static CountryAddressWrapper getCountryAddressWrapper(AddressFillable address, AddressFormatterParameters parameters)
      Wraps an address with country-specific formatting capabilities. This method creates a CountryAddressWrapper that can be used to apply country-specific formatting to the address.
      Parameters:
      address - The address to be wrapped.
      parameters - Parameters that influence the formatting of the address.
      Returns:
      A CountryAddressWrapper that wraps the given address for country-specific formatting.
